metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Raja of Ramgarh

facts.text: Ramgarh Raj is an ancient principality in Bihar with three coalfields: Bokaro Jharia, Bokaro Ramgarh and Karanpura, the latter being the largest at 550 sq. miles, of which 415 sq. miles belonged to the estate.
On 26-11-1907, Raja Ramnarain Singh granted a prospecting license to Messrs Anderson Wright Co. for Bokaro Ramgarh coalfields (Bokaro license).
Raja Ramnarain Singh died on 26-1-1913 leaving widow Rikinath Kaur and minor son Lakshminarain Singh; estate debts amounted to Rs. 9 lakhs.
On 20-5-1913, Court of Wards took over management of the estate.
Messrs Bird and Co. applied for prospecting license for Karanpura coalfields; negotiations led to agreement on 29-7-1914.

Prospecting license granted to Messrs Bird and Co. on 26-3-1915 for 6 years; salami Rs. 1,00,000; minimum ground rent Rs. 8,000 from second year; advance loan Rs. 9 lakhs interest-free, adjustable against royalties; mortgage bond executed.
On 3-8-1915, Messrs Bird and Co. applied for extension due to war conditions.

Deed dated 23-11-1917 modified 1915 license: extended to 12 years (to 26-3-1927), further extensions conditional on taking leases of 10,000 bighas (to 1939) and 20,000 bighas (to 1951); minimum ground rent Rs. 50,000 p.a. from 7th-12th year.
Raja Lakshminarain Singh became major on 6-4-1919 and died on 10-4-1919 leaving minor son Raja Kamakshya Narain Singh.
Court of Wards continued management until 10-8-1937 when Raja Kamakshya Narain Singh became major.
Appellant Company registered on 14-7-1920, took over interests of Bird & Co.
Appellant took six leases covering 17,539 bighas between 17-7-1922 and 17-7-1933.
Deed dated 1-6-1937 modified clause 6 of 1917 deed: minimum royalty on excess over 10,000 bighas postponed until railway facilities or 26-3-1951.
Appellant obtained three leases on 2-8-1937 covering 2,461 bighas to make up 20,000 bighas.
On 9-3-1939, Raja repudiated 1915 license and 1917, 1937 deeds.
Appellant notice on 14-5-1940 demanding lease for 250 bighas; filed Title Suit No. 28/1940 on 8-6-1940 for specific performance.
Raja filed Title Suit No. 82/1940 on 9-8-1940 declaring deeds void and seeking possession with mesne profits.
Subordinate Judge, Hazaribagh on 30-4-1943: 1915 and 1917 deeds valid, 1937 invalid; specific performance in Suit 28, partial relief in Suit 82.
Raja appealed: F.A. 125/1943 (Suit 82), F.A. 127/1943 (Suit 28); Company cross-objections in 125.
Patna High Court: All three deeds invalid; leases void; dismissed Suit 28 and cross-objections.
Estate vested in State of Bihar under Bihar Land Reforms Act.
State of Bihar memo accepting leases as valid but reserving right to modify.

legal_issues.text: Validity of prospecting license dated 26-3-1915 granted by Court of Wards.
Validity of deed dated 23-11-1917 modifying the 1915 license.
Validity of deed dated 1-6-1937 further modifying terms.
Scope of powers of Court of Wards under Section 18 of Bengal Court of Wards Act, 1879: whether judgment 'as it may judge' is subjective or objective.
Whether sanction under Section 18 was obtained for the deeds.

petitioner_arguments.text: Court of Wards applied its mind to cess clause in 1915 deed; difference from Bokaro license is formal, not substantive, as per Bengal Cess Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Cess Act IX of 1880, Sections 80, 81

petitioner_arguments.text: 1917 deed within powers under Section 18; sanction obtained via letters dated 3-7-1916 and 9-10-1917.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Court of Wards Act, Section 18; Gulabsingh v. Seth Gokuldas; Ramkanai Singh Deb v. Mathewson

petitioner_arguments.text: Leases of 1937 valid despite 1937 deed invalidity; proviso severable.
No challenge to invalidity of 1937 deed.

respondent_arguments.text: 1915 deed not beneficial due to cess clause less advantageous than Bokaro license; Court of Wards did not apply mind.
1917 deed beyond powers: ties estate for 32 years post-majority, binds to old rates, like a gift; not beneficial; no sanction; considered only Bird's benefit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Court of Wards Act, Section 18

respondent_arguments.text: 1937 deed invalid, no sanction, not beneficial; 1937 leases void as incorporating invalid clause without sanction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Court of Wards Act, Section 18

court_reasoning.text: Court of Wards is statutory body; powers under S.18(14) to do what proprietor might do; S.18 allows acts 'as it may judge' for benefit - subjective judgment, not objective; challenge only for fraud, non-application of mind, or no bona fides.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'as it may judge' confer authority to Court of Wards alone; not reviewable on merits.

court_reasoning.text: Cess clause in 1915 deed approved after scrutiny by officers, legal adviser, Board; applied mind; not negligent as statutory body.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence shows deliberation; difference with Bokaro not substantive.

court_reasoning.text: 1917 deed within S.18: no limit on term tied to minority; considered estate benefit (long-term exploitation, war conditions); mutual obligations, not gift.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correspondence shows consideration of estate interests.

court_reasoning.text: Sanction for 1917 deed via Board letters 3-7-1916 (general) and 9-10-1917 (essential terms); no need for final draft approval.
1937 deed invalid (conceded); but 1937 leases valid, proviso severable; sanction covers transaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Invalid clause does not void whole lease.

holdings.text: Deeds dated 26-3-1915 and 23-11-1917 valid and binding; executed under S.18 with proper sanction and judgment.
Leases valid; clause in 1937 leases postponing royalty inoperative.
S.18 judgment subjective; not reviewable unless no application of mind or mala fides.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nakkuda Ali v. M.F. De S. Jayaratne
precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of words implying reasonable grounds vs subjective judgment.
Words like 'reasonable cause to believe' import objective standard.

precedents_cited.case_name: Allcroft v. Lord Bishop of London
precedents_cited.relevance: Limits of judicial interference with honest statutory judgment.
Sanction under S.18 need not cover precise terms, only essentials.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramkanai Singh Deb Darpashaha v. Mathewson
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction of transaction essentials suffices even if final deed not submitted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict construction against contracting out of statutory cess liability.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Court of Wards Act IX of 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of Court of Wards to manage estate and sanction acts for benefit; subjective judgment.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Cess Act IX of 1880
statutes_cited.relevance: Cess on mines borne equally by owner and lessee.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Land Reforms Act XXX of 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of estate in State of Bihar.

statutes_cited.name: Guardians and Wards Act VIII of 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: Contrasted; no similar term limit for Court of Wards.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court decrees set aside; trial court decrees restored. 1915 and 1917 deeds valid, leases valid except royalty postponement clause in 1937 leases inoperative. Costs: Appellant costs in CA 191 throughout; parties bear own in CA 192.
outcome.relief_granted: Specific performance in Suit 28; leases upheld subject to clause invalidity.
outcome.costs: Appellant costs in C.A. No. 191 of 1953 throughout; parties bear own costs in C.A. No. 192 of 1953.

key_quotes.text: "The statute confides in clear and unambiguous terms the authority to judge whether the act is beneficial to the estate, to the Court of Wards and not to any outside authority."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines subjective nature of S.18 power.

key_quotes.text: "A transaction entered into by a guardian on behalf of a minor will be valid and binding on the latter, only if it is for proved necessity or benefit. When a transaction is entered into by a Court of Wards on behalf of the ward, is its validity to be judged on the same considerations?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes Court of Wards from natural guardian.

key_quotes.text: "The sanction which is to be inferred from the letter... empowered the Court of Wards to mortgage the property under section 18."
key_quotes.speaker: court
